required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Performance of Lung Ultrasonography for Endotracheal Tube Positioning in Neonates
clinical_study.official_title: Performance of Lung Ultrasonography for Endotracheal Tube Positioning in Neonates

brief_summary.textblock: Lung Ultrasonography (US) has been shown to be effective for verifying endotracheal tube (ETT) position in adults and children but has been less studied in neonates. The aim of this study is to evaluate the performance of lung US in determining correct ETT position in neonates, in comparison with X Ray

primary_outcome.measure: Concordance of ETT positioning according to lung ultrasonography with chest X ray results
primary_outcome.description: X Ray correct ETT position : ETT's tip will be correctly positioned if located between the upper edge of the first thoracic vertebra and the lower edge of the second thoracic vertebra. Ultrasound correct ETT position : ETT'S tip will be correctly positioned if the distance between ETT's tip and the junction of the brachycephalic artery with aortic arch will be measured between 0.8 and 1.5 centimeter

secondary_outcome.measure: time of realization chest X ray
secondary_outcome.description: time of realization chest X ray
Concordance of thoracic ultrasound results between the operator and the reviewer

intervention.description: The ultrasound of the thorax will be performed while waiting for the X-ray thorax

study_pop.textblock: Newborns treated with mechanical ventilation and required chest X ray for determining ETT position

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Newborns
- treated with mechanical ventilation
- and required chest X ray for determining ETT position
- hospitalised in neonatal intensive Care unit , Limoges, France
- signed parental inform consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Congenital heart disease

clinical_study.keyword: diagnostic imaging, Newborn, Intubation, Ultrasonography methods
